answers.answer: Emphysematous cholecystitis is an acute infection of the gallbladder wall caused by gas-forming organisms. Diabetes mellitus is an important risk factor. CT scan is emerging as the most sensitive and specific diagnostic study. Management of emphysematous cholecystitis is usually surgicalPlain film shows-- Air in the wall and lumen of gall bladder is noted seen in the right upper quadrant of the film provided.CT shows-air in lumen of gallbladder with thickened gallbladder wall and minmal pericholecystic stranding; gall bladder is distended.

question: A 89-year old woman comes in with severe abdominal pain.History of the Present Illness: She is confused and cannot describe her symptoms Her husband provides a limited history of nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain since 3 days agoPast Medical History: The patient has diabetes mellitus, hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and sick sinus syndrome with a pacemaker The patient's medications include metformin, indapamide, pantoprazole, and aspirinPhysical Examination: The patient is lethargic but opens her eyes when called; sleepy but arousable and conversant She is not oriented to time or place and slips back into sleep when not actively spoken to T – 360C; BP - 100/67 mm Hg; PR - 100 bpm; RR - 18 cpm; O2 saturation - 96% on room air Head and Neck - unremarkable Heart - paced rhythm with a 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border; Lungs - coarse rales at bilateral bases Abdomen: distended and tender mostly at the right upper and lower quadrants; ⊕ guarding but ⊖ rebound tenderness The remaining physical findings are unremarkablePlease help me interpret the radiographs, this is the link to the pictures. thanks!Xray 1st HD: http://img161.imageshack.us/my.php?image=1hdqt7.jpgXray 2nd HD: http://img210.imageshack.us/my.php?image=2hdxc5.jpgct scan: http://img259.imageshack.us/my.php?image=ctkr8.jpg
title: emphysematous cholecystitis??
